Why Christian McCaffrey Deserves the Heisman Trophy

Back in September, he was merely Ed McCaffrey’s son. Thirteen games later, he is in New York, attending the presentation for college football’s most prestigious trophy.

On the field, Stanford’s running back Christian McCaffrey can do it all. He is the prototype of a multidimensional player on the gridiron. In the Pac-12 championship against USC, he threw for a touchdown, ran for a touchdown, and caught a touchdown pass. He looked dominant against a myriad of Pac-12 defenses all year — his finest performance was a 243-yard, four touchdown effort against an 8–4 UCLA team on a Thursday night.

As a runner, McCaffrey is almost as good as they get. He ranks second in the nation behind fellow Heisman candidate Derrick Henry in total rushing yards. He posted at least 100 yards on the stat sheet in all 10 games versus Pac-12 opponents this year. Stanford is currently ranked #6 in the AP poll, and they can thank McCaffrey for that position in the polls. He was the centerpiece of the high-octane Stanford offense after the Northwestern game this year.

McCaffrey’s 540 receiving yards rank second among all college football running backs this season. His brother, Max McCaffrey, was a starting receiver at Duke and only had 601! McCaffrey is one of the favorite targets of fifth-year senior quarterback Kevin Hogan, and provides Stanford an extra, reliable threat in the passing game.

McCaffrey is one of the most electrifying kick returners in the nation. While he only scored one touchdown on special teams, his 1,042 kick return yards rank second in the nation. It doesn’t matter if the ball enters his hands from a kickoff, a pass, or a handoff — McCaffrey turns into a bull whenever the pigskin is in his possession. With a 6'1", 201-pound frame, McCaffrey runs with strength and speed, shedding off tackles and subsequently blazing down the field.

McCaffrey is such a versatile player and seems to be almost perfect at all aspects of college football. So how can somebody else even contend for Heisman? Enter Derrick Henry, the next product of Alabama’s long line of dominant running backs. Henry rushed for 1,986 yards in his first 13 games with an astounding 23 touchdowns, compared to McCaffrey’s eight. Henry is a remarkable football player and it is difficult to discredit his Heisman résumé, but where is his versatility? Henry does not contribute to as many aspects of the game as McCaffrey does. He is rarely used in any situation on the field that doesn’t involve a basic running play behind his offensive linemen.

Alabama has been better than almost any college at producing NFL-caliber linemen (D.J. Fluker, Andre Smith, Chance Warmack, etc.). The success of Alabama running backs (Mark Ingram, Eddie Lacy, T.J. Yeldon, etc.) in college are additional proof that almost any running back can be placed in Alabama’s dominant offensive system and produce similar stats. If you placed Christian McCaffrey behind those Alabama linemen, he could produce exactly what Derrick Henry did. If you placed Derrick Henry on the Farm in California and utilized him in McCaffrey’s various roles, it would be very difficult for him to find similar success. McCaffrey is a rare gem of a football player, and there are very few who have played the game who share his versatility.

This Heisman race mirrors the 2009 Heisman battle between Alabama running back Mark Ingram and Stanford running back Toby Gerhart. In the 2009 race, Gerhart had better rushing statistics than Ingram, but Ingram was a crucial member of an undefeated Alabama team. Voters have been likely swayed by team’s records in the past, as they were in 2009, and that could be one reason Henry gets a nod from voters instead of McCaffrey. Alabama is in the playoff, Stanford is not. Since 2006, six out of nine of the Heisman Trophy winners have played in either the College Football Playoff or the BCS National Championship Game.

No matter who the voters select to win the Heisman, Christian McCaffrey had an incredible, record-breaking season like no other we’ve seen before. He is only a sophomore and may continue to post similar results in the Rose Bowl against Iowa and in future years with Stanford. But a player should be rewarded for his ability to play different parts of the game, and play them at a high level.

The Heisman Memorial Trophy annually recognizes the outstanding college football player whose performance best exhibits the pursuit of excellence with integrity. Winners epitomize great ability combined with diligence, perseverance, and hard work.

The Heisman Trophy’s mission statement defines Christian McCaffrey’s 2015 season.
